I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed equity 
investment of up to $60,000,000 in Creador V L.P. 
 
2.  Creador represents, as a group, a regional private equity fund manager headquartered in 
Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia that invests in companies located or with significant business activities 
in countries across South Asia and Southeast Asia (with a core focus on India, Indonesia, 
Malaysia, the Philippines, and Viet Nam).1 The fund may also invest in Bangladesh, Singapore, 
Sri Lanka, and Thailand on an opportunistic basis (para. 10). If approved, this would be the third 
investment of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in a Creador-managed fund (para. 5 contains 
details of ADB’s earlier investments). 
 
3.  Creador V L.P. (Creador V) proposes to make primarily growth equity investments in 
companies  operating  in  the  business  services,  consumer  goods  and services,  health  care 
(including pharmaceuticals), financial services, and manufacturing segments. As a result of ADB's 
investment, Creador V will be required to adopt enhanced environmental and social (E&S) 
requirements to strengthen its investee companies’ safeguards standards. Further, ADB intends 
Creador V to be the first Creador-managed fund to incorporate gender elements with assistance 
from ADB’s private sector gender team. By incorporating ADB’s proposed gender initiatives, 
Creador V is expected to improve access to social, economic, and financial resources and 
opportunities  for  women,  support  women’s  economic  empowerment  by  promoting  greater 
financial inclusion of women through investments in appropriate businesses, and strengthen 
gender equality in Creador’s operations. 
 
II.  THE FUND  
 
A.  Investment Identification and Description 
 
4.  Description. Creador was established in 2011 in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia by its chief 
executive officer (CEO) Brahmal Vasudevan, a seasoned private equity investment professional. 
Vasudevan leads a large and experienced team of 42 professionals comprising 22 investment 
professionals and 20 strategy and operating professionals. As a regional fund manager, Creador 
maintains a local presence and has offices in India, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, and 
Viet Nam. Since its inception in 2011, Creador has raised four funds totaling $1.5 billion in 
committed capital, investing about $1.2 billion across 41 investments as of 31 March 2021. 
 
5.  Investment identification. As an existing investor in Creador III L.P. ($40.9 million 
commitment approved in November 2015) and Creador IV L.P. ($49.9 million commitment 
approved in September 2018),2 ADB understands the Creador platform well. ADB’s relationship 
with Creador dates to 2014 when ADB identified the fund manager through a comprehensive 
market mapping exercise of Southeast Asia as a potential partner based on  Vasudevan’s 
reputation as an astute investor during his time at ChrysCapital in India and the developing track 
record of Creador’s first two funds. 
 
6.  ADB’s overarching development goal in investing in Creador V is to support growing and 
well-managed middle-market companies (with revenues of at least $10 million) in Southeast Asia

and South Asia to realize their expansion plans, thereby increasing employment, tax generation, 
access to health and financial services, and regional growth. By supporting an established 
regional private equity manager such as Creador, ADB seeks to attract and mobilize equity growth 
capital into markets with strong macroeconomic fundamentals driven by compelling demographic 
profiles, growing middle classes driving domestic consumption, and established export linkages 
with North America and Europe.

8.  In addition, access to capital for women is generally considered an important driver to 
advance women’s economic empowerment and progress on gender equality in South and 
Southeast Asia. Yet, women are significantly underrepresented globally as investment decision-
makers and founders of investee companies at private equity and venture capital firms. In 2019, 
companies founded by women received just 2.7% of global venture capital funding compared with 
the 85.8% going to all-male founder teams.3 While very few firms apply a gender lens approach 
to their investments, gender lens financing (defined as a financing strategy intentionally looking 
at gender factors in investments toward advancing women in companies and/or advancing 
companies that promote a positive impact on women) is gaining important traction in Southeast 
Asia.4 In  the  past,  many  investors  have  reported  difficulty  in  identifying  gender  qualified 
enterprises since their understanding of gender lens investing was limited to companies that are 
directly financing businesses owned or led by women. However, the most common strategies 
used by gender lens investors have expanded to include providing critical goods and services to 
women and supporting businesses led and owned by women.5 As a result of these expanded 
elements, gender lens investing is having a significant development impact, especially in financial 
services, agriculture, and workforce development. 
 
9.  Further, the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to support the 
economies  of  South  and  Southeast  Asia  with  greater  capital  investments  to  tackle  the 
development  challenges  exacerbated  by  weakened  consumer  demand,  declining  exports, 
depressed domestic investments, and rising unemployment. ADB’s participation in Creador V will, 
therefore, contribute to increased availability of critical growth capital at a time when funding for 
new investments (particularly from banks) is constrained and when financial institutions and 
investors are increasingly risk averse. 
 
B.  Business Overview and Strategy 
 
10.  With an expected size of $600 million, Creador V aims to construct a portfolio of 10–12 
growth investments with ticket sizes averaging $20 million–$75 million each. The fund will seek 
mainly minority stakes, but may also selectively pursue control and roll up opportunities. Target 
companies will have significant business operations in South and/or Southeast Asia.6 Focus

17.  Upon consummation of an investment, the Creador+ team actively engages with the 
investee company in areas where Creador’s due diligence has identified areas of growth and 
improvement. These areas include strategic planning, cost minimization, optimization of supply 
chain  and  distribution  channels,  streamlining  of  accounting  and  finance  functions,  talent 
acquisition, and capital raising. The Creador+ team regularly tracks the operational and financial 
data of portfolio companies to identify operational issues early. The initial Creador+ engagement 
is typically for the first 3–6 months after Creador’s investment. During this time, Creador+ works 
closely with the management team of the investee company to establish appropriate business 
targets and/or finalize operating budgets. Depending on the progress of the initial engagement 
and extent of the gaps identified, particularly if a business is underperforming, Creador+ continues 
to be actively involved in managing the company’s operations and may even deploy its own staff

III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  The Assistance 
 
20.  ADB intends to make an equity investment of up to $60 million in Creador V, representing 
10% of the targeted fund size. ADB’s investment will not exceed 25% of Creador V’s total 
committed capital and will not result in ADB being the single largest investor in Creador V. 
 
B.  Financial Analysis of Expected Returns and Assumptions 
 
21.  [This information has been removed as it falls under the exception to disclosure in ADB’s 
Access to Information Policy, para. 17.2.(v)]. 
 
C.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
22.  Exit strategy. Creador V has a 10-year term from its final closing date, which can be 
extended by two 1-year periods, with the consent of a majority in interest of the fund’s limited 
partners. The exit strategies for Creador V’s investments include public offerings on global stock 
exchanges, trade sales of portfolio companies to strategic buyers, and secondary sales to other 
private equity funds. 
 
23.  Reporting arrangements. The general partner will be required to provide ADB with 
unaudited quarterly reports, audited annual reports with financial statements, a fund overview, 
annual development effectiveness monitoring reports, and an overview of the portfolio. ADB will 
review this information and follow up with the general partner if more information or clarification is 
needed. If the information received from the general partner raises issues that could impair the 
value of ADB’s investment in Creador V, ADB could decide to put the fund on a watch list for more 
frequent and detailed reviews. 
 
D.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
 
24.  Gender inclusiveness. The general partner has committed to adopt measures promoting 
gender equality across Creador V’s operations by introducing and implementing a gender lens 
investing approach in the fund’s portfolio and enhancing gender-inclusive workplace practices. 
ADB has worked with the general partner to design a gender action plan, which the general

25.  Environmental and social standards. ADB’s participation will obligate the fund to adopt, 
and to require Creador V’s investee companies to adopt, ADB’s E&S safeguard policies and 
requirements, and report on development indicators (footnote 21). In this context, Creador 
informed ADB of its intention to build out a dedicated in-house E&S team to oversee the execution 
of the fund’s environmental and social management system (ESMS) for Creador V and its prior 
funds. In response to Creador’s request, ADB is providing guidance in recruiting a well-qualified 
E&S professional to head this team. ADB is also working with Creador to enhance the fund’s E&S 
due diligence, monitoring, and reporting processes (para. 42). 
 
26.  Governance oversight. ADB, along with other members of Creador V’s advisory board, 
will also provide oversight on important governance matters including issues relating to conflicts 
of interest.

IV.  DEVELOPMENT IMPACT AND STRATEGIC ALIGNMENT 
 
A.  Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
33.  Impact. Access to growth capital for middle-market companies in South and Southeast 
Asia in Creador V’s target sectors improved at a time when capital availability for new investments 
is constrained and when financial institutions and investors are increasingly risk averse given 
uncertainties caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. 
 
34.  Outcome. Private equity investments to improve funding for middle-market companies in 
targeted sectors in South and Southeast Asia expanded. 
 
35.  Outputs. The outputs are (i) Creador V is successfully established, and (ii) gender equality 
in Creador operations introduced.

B.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
 
36.  Consistency  with  ADB  strategy.  The  investment  in  Creador  V  aligns  with  ADB’s 
Strategy 2030 operational priority 1 (addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequalities), 
which mandates ADB to undertake efforts to generate quality jobs to support inclusive growth for 
all.13 This  investment  also  aims to  accelerate  progress  on  gender  equality,  contributing to 
Strategy 2030 operational priority 2, which calls for scaling up support for gender equality and 
promoting women’s empowerment through increasing financial inclusion, supporting women’s 
entrepreneurship, and improving access to job skills. 
 
37.  Consistency  with  country  strategies.  The  proposed  investment  in  Creador  V  is 
consistent with ADB’s country partnership strategy (CPS) for Indonesia, which prioritizes inclusive 
growth by improving job creation, deepening financial markets, and strengthening the health care 
system.14 The investment is also aligned with ADB’s CPS for India, which highlights fostering 
regional cooperation and supporting the manufacturing, health, and education sectors as strategic 
priorities.15 In the Philippines, ADB’s CPS highlights promoting local investments as one of its 
three pillars.16 Similarly, the proposed investment is consistent with ADB’s CPS for Viet Nam, 
which places emphasis on promoting job creation and competitiveness, supporting small and 
medium-sized business enterprises, and improving access to services.17 
 
38.  Consistency with sector strategy and relevant ADB operations. The investment in 
Creador V is consistent with ADB’s operational plan for private sector operations, which supports 
investments in private equity funds that enable ADB to deploy and mobilize equity capital 
efficiently to support companies in realizing their expansion plans, thereby generating strong 
multiplier effects on ADB’s capital.18 
  
39.  Lessons from previous operations. A corporate evaluation of ADB’s private sector 
equity  investments  concluded  that  ADB  should  refine  its  approach  to  private  equity  fund 
investments  to  ensure  their  financial  sustainability  and  to  prioritize  value  addition  and 
development impact.19 In this project, ADB is making a third investment in a Creador-managed 
 
fund. Given ADB’s ongoing, strong relationship with Creador, which formally began in 2015 with 
an investment in Creador III L.P., ADB is comfortable with the management and investment 
teams’ experience and track record, Creador’s investment strategy for South and Southeast Asia, 
and the quality of Creador’s deal pipeline. Further, ADB builds on the experience that the general 
partner’s mandate in Asia (consistent with prior funds in which ADB has invested) aligns strongly 
with ADB’s areas of development focus and conforms to a rigorous multistage underwriting 
process that identifies potential market leading companies with strong management teams. 
Therefore, the project team is proceeding with the investment upon confirmation through its due 
diligence  that  Creador  V  meets  the  criteria  of  financial  sustainability,  value  addition,  and 
development impact.

V.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
 
40.  ADB  has  categorized  the  investment  in  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement (2009).20 
 
41.  Category FI. The project is classified category FI for impacts on environment, involuntary 
resettlement, and indigenous peoples in compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. The 
fund’s potential E&S impacts, the risks associated with existing and likely future portfolio, and its 
commitment and capacity for E&S management have been assessed as part of the safeguards’ 
due diligence process. The fund’s business activities are expected to be similar to Creador III L.P. 
and Creador IV L.P.  
 
42.  Creador’s existing ESMS (dated April 2020) applies ADB’s prohibited investment activities 
list; has procedures in place to screen, assess, and address E&S risks of investee companies; 
and has provisions requiring the fund to oblige investee companies to operate in accordance with 
applicable national laws and regulations and to implement any corrective action plan.21 To 
strengthen the fund’s ESMS implementation, Creador is committed to (i) engage a dedicated and 
qualified E&S manager and strengthen its E&S capacity, (ii) enhance its process for engagement 
with ADB during investment due diligence, (iii) enhance its monitoring and data collection of 
investee companies, (iv) enhance its E&S reporting to ADB, (v) enhance the grievance redress 
mechanism to cover all portfolio companies, and (vi) prepare an E&S training program tailored to 
the needs of the organization. ADB will have the right to be excused from contributing capital to 
any  investment  classified  category  A  (for  all  safeguard  classifications)  and  any  proposed 
investment that it assesses as being noncompliant with the ESMS. 
 
43.  Effective  gender mainstreaming.  From the  gender  analysis  conducted  during  due 
diligence, Creador had not previously included gender in the discussions with investee companies 
and has not institutionalized practices regarding gender equality. Following ADB’s Policy on 
Gender  and  Development  (1998),  Creador  has  incorporated  measures  to  promote  gender 
equality and women’s empowerment in its business activities. Key features of the gender action 
plan include (i) developing a gender equality scorecard for the fund’s investment screening 
process, (ii) making recommendations on gender equality practices to the investee companies, 
(iii) developing a diversity and inclusion policy in view of intentionally applying gender equality 
principles in human resources management, and (iv) conducting training sessions for staff on 
gender equality topics covering both the introduction of a gender lens investment tool (gender 
equality scorecard) and a gender-sensitive working environment (footnote 13). Creador will 
submit periodic reports on the implementation of gender measures to ADB.

practice relating to combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB

D.  Assurances 
 
46.  Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),22 
ADB will proceed with the assistance upon establishing that the governments of ADB members 
where Creador V will invest using ADB finance have no objection to the proposed assistance to 
Creador V. ADB will enter into suitable finance documentation, in form and substance satisfactory 
to ADB, following approval of the proposed assistance by the Board of Directors. 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
47.  I am satisfied that the proposed equity investment would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the 
equity investment of up to $60,000,000 from ADB’s ordinary capital resources in Creador V L.P., 
with such terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in this 
report, and as may be reported to the Board.

metadata.Subject:
Creador V L.P. (Creador V) proposes to make primarily growth equity investments in companies operating in the business services, consumer goods and services, health care (including pharmaceuticals), financial services, and manufacturing segments. As a result of ADB's investment, Creador V will be required to adopt enhanced environmental and social (E&S) requirements to strengthen its investee companies’ safeguards standards.   

The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.

This document dated October 2021 is provided for the ADB regional project 55265-001.
